intro: Thottea tapanuliensis, commonly known as the Tapanuli bellflower, is a rare flowering plant native to the highlands of North Sumatra, Indonesia. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, violet-blue flowers. The plant has narrow, grass-like leaves and is adapted to grow in cool, moist environments. It was first discovered in 2015 and is considered critically endangered due to habitat loss. Its botanical significance lies in its unique morphology and role in the biodiversity of its native region.
